utterances: What I'm asking - to be sent to another country which I can start my life.
That's what I want.
Start a family.
Start to finish my college education and to live like a normal person.
That's what I want in my life.
Not more - simple dream.
I'd come to Serbia to find out why men like al-Dayfi, former inmates deemed ready to re-enter society, posed such a problem for the United States.
And right away, I might have found a reason why.
Because even though the Serbs had agreed to take him, they still seemed uncomfortable with an accused terrorist living in their capital city.
The officials I spoke with up to the prime minister said the former detainee in Belgrade was adjusting well.
But as I left our first interview, I was pulled over by Serbian special police.
And then al-Dayfi disappeared.
For two days, he didn't answer his phone or his door.
He then appeared at my hotel, looking terrified with a fresh bruise on his head.
He was certain he'd been followed and that we were being watched in the hotel lobby.
So we went to my room to talk.
And they tried to beat the door.
They beat the door.
He explained the disappearance.
The day after our first interview, he says, several Serbian men wearing masks forced their way into his apartment.
They took me to the ground.
They started threatening like, if you want to stay here, you have to keep your mouth shut.
You are lying.
You are playing games.
Really, I felt humiliated because I never let anyone to touch me that way.
They told me basically, just shut your mouth, and I'm lying.
If you don't stay in this place, we're going to take you someplace where you don't like.
This was a difficult situation, an ex-Guantanamo detainee hiding from authorities in a foreign country, now in my hotel room.
Making the situation more complicated, we still didn't know who al-Dayfi really was.
He was captured in 2001 after the prison uprising in Mazar-e-Sharif and told interrogators he trained with al-Qaida and met repeatedly with Osama bin Laden.
Americans now say he was a low-level fighter who exaggerated his role to sound important.
But if he's lied about being a terrorist, I had to ask him, how could I trust what he said now?
He told me he did what he needed to to survive.
I mean, in Guantanamo, when they put you under pressure, under very bad circumstances, you are going to tell them what they want.
That's it.
It's, like, 72 hours under very cold air conditioning.
And you are tied to the ground.
And someone came and poured cold water - whatever.
Tell him what he want.
Just - OK, get out of my skin.
I will sign anything.
I will admit anything.
Al-Dayfi was in rough shape when I left Serbia in November and more than a dozen pounds lighter than he'd been just weeks before.
He finally ended his hunger strike in December under pressure from his mother.
I kept in touch with al-Dayfi through video calls.
He said he was facing his first real winter without a proper coat.
And he was still miserable.
A few weeks ago, he called me on a Saturday afternoon, tearing through his apartment and ranting.
I start recording.
This is just crazy.
He's ripping the molding of his walls...
There was one in the corner over there.
...Yanking out wires and pulling out tiny, hidden cameras....
Second one is here.
Third one is there.
...Three of them.
I'm really, really pissed off.
This is [expletive] enough.
Really, it's enough.
Being watched on camera in the place where I live.
He had been told he would be monitored.
But cameras in his apartment are too much.
Then it gets worse.
As we're on the call, I see armed men dressed in black ski masks walk in.
Al-Dayfi switches to the front phone camera so I can watch as they search his apartment and demand he hand over the phone he's using to record our conversation.
Al-Dayfi refuses.
And after a standoff, some unmasked officials who speak English arrive.
So can you tell me why I'm being watched in my apartment?
Give me one reason.
Am I a criminal?
They don't have an answer for him but demand his phone again.
Another man identifies himself as a representative of the Serbian government.
You have two choices.
We take your phone now, and you are going to the hospital if you make any kind of problem.
Just listen to me.
I am speaking now.
(Yelling) I'm not giving you my phone.
No, don't talk to me like this.
(Yelling) If you want to kill me, kill me.
I don't care.
I spent 15 [expletive] years in Guantanamo and (unintelligible) against my [expletive] will.
Don't scare me.
Don't scare me, he says.
It sounds like a threat.
Look.
If I was a bad guy - I'm not stupid.
I'm very smart and very dangerous.
I'm very smart and very dangerous.
Those words cut to the heart of the problem.
Is al-Dayfi a real threat or just a desperate man pushed into a corner?
That's exactly what the Serbs want to know.
We don't know who you are.
We - as a state matter, we have to see if you have any other intentions except going back to a normal life, right?
How should I know, like, you are not a threat?
Look.
I have done nothing wrong in my life.
Al-Dayfi pleads, just send me to an Arab country.
You know that you don't probably have opportunity to do it.
With Donald Trump in office, they say, everything has changed.
The Trump administration - it is not the same.
I don't think that you actually have a choice.
There is a sense of resignation at this point and almost humor.
They fall into a very cordial chat for another hour before al-Dayfi finally agrees to let them take his phone and laptop.
They were returned two days later, he says, wiped of data.
Today, 41 detainees remain at Guantanamo.
Ten are scheduled to go on trial in military commissions, including the self-proclaimed mastermind of the 9/11 attacks, Khalid Sheikh Mohammed.
The rest are being held without charge.
President Trump has vowed to stop releases.
Arun Rath, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF THE XX SONG, ""INTRO"")
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And from member station WLRN in Miami, I'm David Greene.
The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, is flush with cash.
It holds as much as $2 billion.
Counterterrorism officials say the group knows how to use that money to its advantage.
It's showing a kind of professional acumen and discipline that sets it apart from other terrorist organizations.
In a series of stories this week, NPR's counterterrorism correspondent Dina Temple-Raston looks at what's behind the success of ISIS.
Dina begins this morning with a look at the kinds of attacks its money can buy.
Back in 2006 when Germany was hosting the World Cup soccer tournament, a terrorist attack was narrowly averted.
Two young men in their twenties boarded commuter trains in the city of Cologne with bombs hidden in their suitcases.
Yes, I do remember that case, and it was pretty low-tech case.
That's Richard Barrett.
He was on a U.N.
team that tallied up the cost of terrorist attacks, including that 2006 attempt in Germany.
These suitcases were meant to blow up on a train.
And, clearly, that would have created a huge amount of damage and public anxiety and so on for very, very little cost.
By very, very little cost, he means less than less than $500.
The bombs were simple - just a propane tank, alarm clock, batteries and a plastic bottle filled with gas.
In fact, Barrett says that one of the men used part of his school tuition money to pay for it all.
It just shows you that attacks do not have to cost $500,000 or $400,000 that people believe 9/11 cost.
Even bigger, more spectactular attacks cost less than you think.
The attack on the London transportation system in 2005 that killed 57 people and injured hundreds - the U.N.
put the total cost of that at about $14,000.
It was self-financed - exactly.
Yeah, I mean, one of the guys was relatively well-off.
His family was relatively well-off.
He was able to get some money, I think.
I think he may even have been a teacher as well.
So he a had salary coming in.

Mohammad Sidique Khan was a teaching assistant, but he was still able to finance one of the deadliest terror attacks against the West since 9/11, which is why it's worrisome that the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, may have millions of dollars available to fund attacks.
Just consider the cost of improvised explosive devices on the battlefield.
The Pentagon has an organization that focuses on IED's, and it published a price list for attacks in Afghanistan in 2012.
What they discovered - a remote-controlled bomb costs about the same as a top-of-the-line iPhone Five or $400.
A suicide bombing vest - it can run as little as $1,200.
A suicide car bomb - between $13,000 and $20,000.
The big variable, the report said, is the cost of the car.
So for ISIS with its reported $2 billion war chest, basically, the only limit on the number of attacks it can launch is the number of people willing to carry them out.
And that, says Juan Zarate, a fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, is the danger ISIS present.
You have a group and a movement that is gaining foothold at the heart of the Middle East with the resources to give manifestation to their wild imaginings.
What's unclear is where those imaginings lead.
ISIS has aspirations for setting up an Islamic state in Iraq.
And it's talked about becoming a regional power, says Georgetown University's Bruce Hoffman.
I think the main question right now is whether it focuses its energies and assets on gaining further ground in Iraq as opposed to, you know, spreading its wing and attacking further afield.
Far enough afield to include the west.
Dina Temple-Raston, NPR News.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
Good morning.
